title: New Jersey Landlord-Tenant Law Reference
disclaimer: This is informational only and does not constitute legal advice. Consult a licensed attorney for legal guidance.
tenantProtectionHighlights: Only state requiring 'good cause' for most evictions
Anti-Eviction Act provides comprehensive tenant protections
Tenants cannot be evicted simply because lease expires
Special protections for seniors and disabled tenants

antiEvictionAct.name: Anti-Eviction Act
antiEvictionAct.appliesTo: All residential tenancies in New Jersey
antiEvictionAct.summary: New Jersey has the strongest tenant protections in the United States. Landlords must have 'good cause' to evict.

goodCauseRequired.description: Landlord MUST prove one of the statutory grounds to evict
goodCauseRequired.importance: This is a CRITICAL protection - lease expiration alone is NOT grounds for eviction

ground1.title: Disorderly Conduct
ground1.description: Tenant has been disorderly, making excessive noise, or disturbing other tenants

ground2.title: Damage to Property
ground2.description: Tenant has willfully or grossly negligently damaged the premises
ground2.noticeRequired: Notice to cease for second offense

ground3.title: Health/Safety Violation
ground3.description: Tenant's conduct is a health or safety hazard to others

ground4.title: Habitual Late Payment
ground4.description: Tenant habitually and substantially fails to pay rent on time
ground4.noticeRequired: Notice to cease required AFTER repeated late payments documented
keyPoints: Must be habitual - not just occasional
Landlord must have accepted late payments previously
Notice to cease gives tenant chance to correct

ground5.title: Criminal Activity
ground5.description: Tenant convicted of drug offense on or near premises

ground6.title: Drug Activity
ground6.description: Tenant is using premises for drug manufacturing or distribution

ground7.title: Violating Lease After Notice
ground7.description: Tenant violated lease terms, given notice to cease, and continues violation
ground7.noticeRequired: Notice to cease THEN notice to quit
process: Step 1: Notice to Cease - describing violation
Step 2: If violation continues, Notice to Quit

ground8.title: Owner Move-In (Owner-Occupied)
ground8.description: For owner-occupied 2-3 family homes only - owner wants to move in
ground8.restrictions: Must genuinely intend to occupy; strong penalties for bad faith

ground9.title: Condo Conversion - Active Senior/Disabled
ground9.description: Condo conversion where tenant is senior or disabled

ground11.title: Removing Permanently from Rental Market
ground11.description: Landlord intends to permanently stop renting the unit
ground11.restrictions: Must genuinely intend to remove from market

ground12.title: Renovation/Demolition
ground12.description: Landlord intends to substantially renovate or demolish
ground12.requirements: Must have permits and genuine intent

ground13.title: Non-Payment of Rent
ground13.description: Tenant failed to pay rent when due
keyPoints: Tenant can pay and stop eviction anytime before judgment

2A:18-61.1.title: Good Cause Required
2A:18-61.1.summary: No judgment for possession shall be entered except on one or more of the grounds specified

2A:18-61.2.title: Notice Requirements
2A:18-61.2.summary: Specifies notice periods required for each ground

2A:18-61.3.title: Protected Tenants
2A:18-61.3.summary: Additional protections for seniors, disabled, and long-term tenants

2A:18-61.11.title: Penalties for Wrongful Eviction
2A:18-61.11.summary: Civil penalties for eviction in violation of the Act

truthInRenting.name: Truth in Renting Act
truthInRenting.summary: Requires landlords to provide tenants with information about their rights
requirements: Landlord must provide Truth in Renting statement to tenant
Must be given at lease signing
Must be in English and Spanish if requested
Failure to provide may affect eviction proceedings
truthInRenting.importance: FAILURE TO PROVIDE TRUTH IN RENTING STATEMENT MAY DELAY EVICTION

securityDeposits.name: Security Deposit Law
keyPoints: Must be deposited in NJ bank within 30 days
Must pay interest at rate set by state
Must return within 30 days of move-out
Must provide written itemization of deductions
Wrongful withholding = 2x deposit plus attorney fees
Failure to properly handle = tenant may apply rent to deposit

tenantRemedy.description: If landlord violates security deposit law, tenant can use deposit as rent

impliedWarranty.name: Implied Warranty of Habitability
impliedWarranty.summary: New Jersey has strong implied warranty of habitability
requirements: Plumbing and heating in working order
tenantRemedies: Sue for damages and rent abatement

selfHelpEviction.name: Self-Help Eviction Prohibition
selfHelpEviction.summary: Self-help evictions are STRICTLY PROHIBITED in New Jersey
selfHelpEviction.penalty: Wrongful eviction can result in significant monetary damages and criminal liability

retaliatoryEviction.name: Anti-Retaliation Protection
protectedActivities: Exercising rights under lease or law
retaliatoryEviction.presumption: Rebuttable presumption of retaliation if eviction within 90 days of protected activity
retaliatoryEviction.remedies: Tenant may recover damages, attorney fees, and obtain injunction

noticePeriods.name: Required Notice Periods
noticePeriods.summary: Notice periods required under New Jersey law

nonpayment.notes: Standard is 30 days; lease may specify shorter (not less than 7 days)
mustInclude: Date by which payment must be made
Statement that failure to pay may result in eviction

leaseViolation.type: Notice to Cease + Notice to Quit
leaseViolation.notes: Two-step process required for most violations
process: Step 1: Notice to Cease - describing violation and demanding it stop
Step 2: If violation continues, Notice to Quit (giving time to vacate)

habitualLatePayment.notes: Must document repeated late payments before serving notice

condoConversion.notes: 3 years notice required for condo conversion
condoConversion.seniorProtected: Additional protections for seniors and disabled

courtSystem.name: New Jersey Court System for Landlord-Tenant
courtSystem.summary: Special Civil Part handles eviction cases

specialCivilPart.name: Superior Court - Special Civil Part
specialCivilPart.description: Landlord-Tenant section handles all eviction cases

seniorDisabledProtection.name: Senior and Disabled Tenant Protection Act
seniorDisabledProtection.summary: Additional protections for seniors and disabled tenants
protectedClasses: Disabled persons receiving Social Security disability
protections: Extended notice periods for condo conversions (3 years)
Right to continue tenancy in converted buildings
Special protections against eviction for sale of property

defenses.description: Landlord failed to provide required 30-day written notice
defenses.howToRaise: File answer alleging insufficient notice; request dismissal

defenses.description: All rent due was paid within the notice period
defenses.howToRaise: Provide receipts showing payment before deadline - STOPS EVICTION

defenses.description: Premises not maintained in habitable condition
defenses.howToRaise: Document conditions; show landlord was notified; may justify rent withholding or abatement

defenses.description: Landlord failed to provide Truth in Renting statement
defenses.howToRaise: Show landlord did not provide required disclosure; may delay eviction

defenses.description: Landlord violated security deposit law - tenant can apply deposit to rent
defenses.howToRaise: Prove security deposit violation; use as rent credit

defenses.description: Landlord accepted partial payment after notice, waiving right to evict
defenses.howToRaise: Show acceptance of payment after notice was served

defenses.description: Eviction filed in response to tenant exercising legal rights
defenses.howToRaise: Show timing between protected activity and eviction filing

defenses.description: Landlord failed to provide Notice to Cease before Notice to Quit
defenses.howToRaise: Show required two-step notice process not followed

defenses.description: Violation was corrected after Notice to Cease
Alleged conduct does not violate lease terms
defenses.howToRaise: Review lease terms; present evidence disproving violation

defenses.description: Landlord enforces provision against tenant but not others
Landlord must allege one of the statutory grounds - lease expiration is NOT enough
defenses.howToRaise: Challenge complaint for failure to state good cause
defenses.strength: CRITICAL DEFENSE - case should be dismissed

defenses.description: The ground alleged does not apply to this situation
defenses.howToRaise: Show the facts don't match the statutory ground

defenses.description: Building does not qualify as owner-occupied 2-3 family home
defenses.howToRaise: Show building is larger than 3 units or not owner-occupied

defenses.description: Landlord does not genuinely intend to occupy unit
defenses.howToRaise: Show landlord's history or intent to re-rent

essex.name: Legal Services of New Jersey - Essex Region
essex.address: 60 Evergreen Place, Suite 400, East Orange, NJ 07018

hudson.name: Legal Services of New Jersey - Hudson Region

courtSystems.general: Superior Court, Special Civil Part - Landlord/Tenant Section

tenantProtectionHighlights: ONLY state requiring 'good cause' for eviction
Lease expiration is NOT grounds for eviction
Security deposit violations = use deposit as rent
